metadata.case_name: Revenue v. Executors of the Estate of Mahendrasinghji

facts.text: The Expenditure-tax Act 29 of 1957 received the assent of the President on September 17, 1957, and was brought into force on April 1, 1958.
His Highness Mahendrasinghji, Ruler of Morvi died on August 17, 1957, having made a will appointing the respondents as executors of his estate.

The Expenditure-tax Officer issued a notice under S. 13(2) of the Expenditure-tax Act, 1947, requiring the respondents to furnish a return of the expenditure incurred by Mahendrasinghji for the period between April 1, 1957 to August 17, 1957.

The respondents submitted that the Act did not apply to Mahendrasinghji because he had died before the date on which the Act came into force, and on that account the respondents as executors were not liable to submit the return demanded.
By letter dated November 19, 1959, the Expenditure-tax Officer rejected the contention raised by the respondents.

The respondents filed a petition in the High Court of Bombay under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the proceedings started by the Expenditure-tax Officer for assessing and levying tax on the expenditure incurred by the late Mahendrasinghji during the previous year be quashed and that the Officer be restrained by an injunction from taking further steps or proceedings under the Act.

The High Court held that the charge under the Act in respect of expenditure incurred in the relevant previous year to the assessment year 1958-59 was not on the estate of any individual or any Hindu undivided family but on the individual or the Hindu undivided family incurring the expenditure, and as it was imposed for the first time on April 1, 1958, unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force, no tax could be levied.
With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

legal_issues.text: Whether the estate of a person who died before the Expenditure-tax Act, 1957 came into force is liable to expenditure-tax under Section 18 of the Act in respect of expenditure incurred by the deceased in the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59.

petitioner_arguments.text: Power of Parliament to enact legislation for assessing tax against the representatives of a person who died before the date on which the Act was brought into force and for collecting it from his estate is not challenged. Section 18 sets up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 2(c), 3, 13, 14, 15, 18 of Expenditure-tax Act, 1957; Section 24B of Income-tax Act, 1922

petitioner_arguments.text: The expression 'Where a person dies' in Section 18(1) imposes liability upon the legal representatives to pay out of the estate the expenditure-tax assessed as payable by such person, or any sum which would have been payable by him if he had not died. There is nothing suggesting restriction to persons dying after the Act was brought into force.

Sub-sections 2 and 3 of Section 18 confer powers upon the Expenditure-tax Officer exercisable against the legal representatives which but for death would have been exercised under Sections 13(2) and 15 against such person.

respondent_arguments.text: The Act does not apply to Mahendrasinghji because he had died before the date on which the Act came into force, and on that account the respondents as executors of his will were not liable to submit the return demanded.

Parliament has failed to set up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so as to render his estate liable under the Act. Section 18 does not bring within the net of taxation cases of persons who died before the Act was brought into force; it only sets up machinery for enforcing liability against the estate of a person dying after the Act is brought into force.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 18 of Expenditure-tax Act, 1957; CIT v. D.N. Mehta (Bombay High Court)

respondent_arguments.text: Parliament having adopted the same phraseology as in Section 24B(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, with the judicial interpretation in CIT v. D.N. Mehta before it, must be deemed to have intended to enact the rule laid down by the Bombay High Court that the estate of a person who died before the Act was brought into force is not liable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 24B Income-tax Act, 1922; CIT v. D.N. Mehta

court_reasoning.text: Section 2(c) defines assessee as an individual or HUF by whom tax is payable, including every individual or HUF against whom proceedings are taken. Assessment year is the year for which tax is chargeable under S.3; previous year as per Income-tax Act.
Section 3 charges tax for every financial year commencing April 1, 1958, in respect of expenditure incurred by any individual or HUF in the previous year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Charge is on the person incurring expenditure.

court_reasoning.text: Section 18(1) imposes liability on executor/administrator/legal representative to pay out of estate the tax assessed as payable by the deceased or which would have been payable if he had not died. Nothing restricts to deaths after Act's force.
Section 18(2) and (3) set up machinery: ETO can require return from legal reps, assess as if deceased alive; Ss.13,14,15 apply to legal reps.
Scheme mirrors S.24B IT Act 1922, inserted to remedy lacuna after Ellis Reid v. CIT. Parliament adopted it for Expenditure-tax Act.

Rejects reliance on CIT v. DN Mehta: Expression 'Where a person dies' does not suggest only future deaths; context of S.18(1)-(3) renders estate liable even if death before Act. No need for explicit 'dies whether before or after'. Argument of inconvenience has no substance.

holdings.text: The estate of a person who died before the Expenditure-tax Act, 1957 was brought into force is liable to expenditure-tax under Section 18 in respect of expenditure incurred by the deceased in the previous year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay HC held assessment proceedings cannot continue against legal reps if assessee dies after notice under S.22(2) IT Act 1922 but before return; led to insertion of S.24B.

precedents_cited.case_name: Income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay HC held S.24B IT Act does not apply to deaths before amendment; used by respondents but rejected by SC as not controlling interpretation of Expenditure-tax Act S.18.

statutes_cited.name: Expenditure-tax Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines assessee, charges tax, provides for returns, assessment, and liability of legal representatives upon death.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Previous year definition; notice for return; machinery for assessment on death inserted by amendment to remedy lacuna, mirrored in Expenditure-tax Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court petition under Art.226 to quash proceedings.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated October 12, 1961, holding that Section 18 of the Expenditure-tax Act, 1957 renders the estate of a person dying before the Act came into force liable to tax on his expenditure in the relevant previous year, with machinery provided for assessment against legal representatives.
outcome.relief_granted: Proceedings against respondents as executors not to be quashed; they are liable to furnish return and face assessment.

key_quotes.text: "Where a person dies, his executor, administrator or other legal representative shall be liable to pay out of the estate of the deceased person... the expenditure-tax assessed as payable by such person, or any sum which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had not died."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key provision interpreted broadly to include pre-Act deaths.

key_quotes.text: There is nothing in the expression 'Where a person dies' or in the context in which it occurs which suggests that it was intended thereby to restrict the operation of the sub-section to cases of persons dying after the Act was brought into force.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has not rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.
key_quotes.speaker: court
